chap.title: To Mr. GEORGE ROMNEY.
chap.head: TO
Mr. GEORGE ROMNEY.
chap.p:
WHILST you was engaged in contemplating tho∫e wonderful productions of ancient art, which ITALY is enriched with, I was tracing the ruder beauties of Nature in a dome∫tic tour thro' the mountainous parts of WESTMORELAND and CUMBERLAND: You carried out with you a di∫interested pa∫∫ion for your art, with faculties which this country hath rarely given birth to; and you return from your travels with ∫ome ∫pecimens of ∫o au∫picious a ∫ort, that, when encouragement ∫hall provoke your genius to its full di∫play, we are per∫uaded you will take rank with the fir∫t
ma∫ters of the highe∫t province and be∫t age of painting: I ∫et out on my expedition with no other preten∫ions than a devout re∫pect for Nature in her ∫ublime∫t ∫hapes, and ∫ome ∫mall leanings towards the Mu∫e; not enough to make our intercour∫e the talk of po∫terity, but barely ∫ufficient to fill up the hour. The fruit of my tour hath been, what I fear is ∫carce worth laying at your feet, the following Irregular Ode, which was literally ∫truck out on the ∫pot, and is addre∫t to the Sun; for as the ∫ea∫on was far advanced towards winter, we had frequent temptations to invoke that luminary, who was never very gracious to our ∫uit, except whil∫t we were viewing the lack of KESWICK and its accompaniments.

If I ∫hould be a∫ked why I give that to the world and you, which I really think ∫carce worthy of the acceptance of you and the world, Ihave only to an∫wer, that if the hone∫t pride of the Friend did not draw it into public, the idle vanity of the Poet would be well content to ∫pare the Pre∫s its pains: but the gratification of ∫aying how much I re∫pect your genius and e∫teem your virtues, finds it an ea∫y ta∫k to overcome the remon∫trances of Judgement, or the terrors of critici∫m.

Mr. GRAY, who∫e faculty of de∫cribing can give life to ∫cenes which I ∫hould have conceived nothing but pencil could convey, hath left behind him a Journal, for which we are indebted to his candid friend and editor. This Journal refers to all the ∫cenes hinted at in the following Ode; and being a book in every body's hands, makes it unnece∫∫ary for me to trouble the Reader with any attempts of my own by way of notes, which with the be∫t of poems ∫eldom accord, and in my in∫tance might have been a hazardous experiment.

How it came to pa∫s, that this enchanting di∫play of ∫ublime and beautiful objects could extort nothing more than a pro∫aic de∫cription from a poetical pen, I am at a lo∫s to gue∫s. I have been favoured with a Manu∫cript of the late ingenious Dr. BROWN, which I have the privilege of in∫erting in this publication, and ∫hould ∫o have done, but that I found it had already got forth into the world, and was in print: It is touched with great ∫pirit, and in a glowing ∫tile, which gradually kindles till it breaks forth into the following rhap∫ody, which I believe hath hitherto e∫caped publication:

line.i: Now ∫unk the Sun, now Twilight ∫unk, and Night
Rode in her zenith; nor a pa∫∫ing breeze
Sigh'd to the groves, which in the midnight air
Stood motionle∫s, and in the peaceful floods
Inverted hung: For now the billow ∫lept
Along the ∫hore, nor heav'd the deep, but ∫pread
A ∫hining mirror to Moon's pale orb,
Which, dim and waining, o'ver the ∫hadowy clifts,
The ∫olemn woods and ∫piry mountain-tops
Her glimmering faintne∫s threw: Now every eye,
Oppre∫s'd with toil, was drown'd in deep repo∫e;
Save that the un∫een ∫heperd in his watch,
Propt on his crook, ∫tood li∫t'ning by the fold,
And gaz'd the ∫tarry vault and pendant moon;
Nor voice nor ∫ound broke on the deep ∫eren,
But the ∫oft murmur of ∫wift-gu∫hing rills,
Forth-i∫∫uing from the mountain's di∫tant ∫leep,
(Unheard till now, and now ∫carce heard) proclaim'd
All things at re∫t, and imag'd the ∫till voice
Of quiet whi∫pering to the ear of Night.

chap.p:
In fine, ∫ays Dr. BROWNE, this accumulation of beauty and immen∫ity tends not only to excite the rapture but reverence; for my part I make an annual voyage to Ke∫wick, not only as an innocent amu∫ement, but a religious
act. I walk forth in this ∫tupendous ∫cene, as into the grande∫t earthly temple of the Creator; and as I take my proge∫s thro' its ∫everal parts, often break forth with the divine P∫almi∫t in that grateful exclamation -- "O LORD, how manifold are thy works; "in wi∫dom ha∫t thou made them all."

What I have here in∫erted is taken from a letter to a friend, and is a valuable ∫pecimen of the author. As for the minute delineations, which ∫ome travellers affect to give of ∫cenes that come under their contemplation, they ∫eldom convey to my apprehen∫ion any map of the place they de∫cribe. To you perhaps, who∫e pictures are language, language may be a picture; and as I know you can paint our very words, words may in return paint that to you, of which a le∫s intuitive mind takes no conception; the bulk of mankind however collect little from the∫e de∫criptions but the amu∫ement of reading them; and the mo∫t they can effect is to refre∫h the memories of them, who have been on the ∫pot, or to in∫pire tho∫e, who have not been, with a re∫olution of going thither. And in truth a more plea∫ing tour than the∫e lakes hold out to men of lei∫ure and curio∫ity cannot be devi∫ed. We penetrate the Glacieres, traver∫e the Rhone and the Rhine, whilst our own dome∫tic lakes of
Ul∫water, Ke∫wick and Windermere exhibit ∫cenes in ∫o ∫ublime a ∫tile, with ∫uch beautiful colourings of rock, wood and water, backed with ∫o tremendous a di∫po∫ition of mountains, that if they do not fairly take the lead of all the views in Europe, yet they are indi∫putably ∫uch as no Enli∫h traveller ∫hould leave behind him, provided he be one, who, with my Atticus, loves

poem.line: "To follow nature in her ∫imple haunts,
"With early ∫teps to climb the ∫haggy ∫ide
"Of ∫ome hoar cliff and meet the dewy breath
"Of morning, i∫∫uing from the flowery vale:
"Or ∫oft reclining on the mo∫∫y turf
"Carele∫s to lye, and, as the dimpling brook
"Steals gently on, with motionle∫s regard
"To eye the floating mirror; while as fa∫t
"Down Meditation's ∫mooth and ∫ilent tide
"In ea∫y lap∫e his tuneful moments fall,
"Clear and untroubled as the pa∫∫ing ∫tream."

chap.p:
But the views of our young travelling gentry, as you mu∫t well know, are not thus directed: on the road they are couriers; in the cities they are revellers: Whil∫t they are journeying there is no re∫pite
nor repo∫e; their enquiries extend neither to right hand nor left, and ∫eldom further forward than to the next po∫te; the ∫horte∫t and ∫traighte∫t road to di∫∫ipation and plea∫ure is their's, all the re∫t is out of the way: but if their cour∫e ∫hould nece∫∫arily carry them up to any thing curious in nature, if their road ∫hould compel them to the banks of a torrent, or the brow of a mountain, they are a∫leep, or it is dark night and they cannot ∫ee it, for they are in ha∫te, and want to be at the next great noi∫y town: And now begins the plan of all their operations; here they lay in their ∫tock of new cloathes, new ta∫te and new opinions; in return for which they barter away all their little fund of money, mode∫ty and religion: Here they walk thro' palaces of pictures with as much edification as a boarding-∫chool girl would thro' the Mu∫eum, or an uphol∫terer thro' the Vatican. They have been told of the gu∫to of the antique, but where to find it, or how to di∫tingui∫h it, they know no more than their mothers: Virtù however is to be purcha∫ed, like other ∫uperfluities, and in the end their Cicerone lays them in for a bargain, perhaps a patch-work head of Trajan ∫et upon a modern pair of ∫houlders, and made up with Caracalla's no∫e and Nero's ears,

line.i: Aut curios jam dimidios, humerove minorem
Corvinum, aut Galbam auriculis na∫oque carentem.

chap.p: Thus equipt with the∫e imperial reliques, with an veritable daubing of Raphaelle, copied from the very print which is given to prove its originality, and a huge cameo on his little finger, home they come privileg'd Virtuo∫i, qualified to condemn every thing that their own countrymen can produce; and thus having contributed all that in them lies to di∫grace their native land, they conclude their career by affecting to de∫pi∫e it. It is in vain that a native arti∫t exhibits to their view the models of a Mars and a Venus, ∫uch as I am bold to ∫ay would have done credit to Athens in its pure∫t age; they may moulder in his ∫hop for them, unle∫s indeed they had lo∫t a leg or an arm in the ruins of Hadrian's villa, and then they would purcha∫e them at twice the cost of the whole figures,
chap.note: It is ∫uperfluous to ∫ay that this points at Mr. Bacon; the reader of ta∫te will be ∫orry to know that the∫e beautiful models have brought nothing but reputation to their maker.

line.i: Miranturque nihil ni∫i quod Libitina ∫acravit.

chap.p: I ∫hould be much mi∫under∫tood if this was not thought to be ∫aid with all due expectations; much more, if I was ∫uppo∫ed in∫en∫ible to the general u∫es of travel: this would be only combating one prejudice with another; let both be ca∫t a∫ide and men and things con∫idered in their true light: There are to be found (and many their number multiply!) protectors of living genius, who will admit the Orpheus of Dance and the Ugolino of Reynolds into their choice∫t cabinets; and I tru∫t there will be found, with whom your Graces will find an honourable ∫tation; for ∫ure it would be a very anti-patriotic prejudice to admit the vulgar drabs of the Flemi∫h, or the theatrical dames of the Italian arti∫t, in preference to a fairer and cha∫ter progeny, for no better rea∫on than becau∫e tho∫e were foreigners, and the∫e of Enli∫h parentage:

line.i: Indignor quicquam reprehendi, non quia cra∫∫e
Compo∫itum inlepideve putetur, ∫ed quia nuper:
Nec veniam antiquis, ∫ed honorem et præmia po∫ci.

chap.p: This is a depravity of ta∫te that does real injury to the genius of the nation, and ∫hould for that rea∫on be combated by every weapon that can ∫erve to root out ∫o noxious an infatuation.

note.i: The readie∫t weapon for this office is ridicule. Comedy could not be better employed than in holding up to view a character of the above de∫cription; ∫uch prejudices militate as much again∫t antient Art and Science as again∫t modern: I wi∫h ∫ome of my brother dramati∫ts, who have more lei∫ure than I have, would accept and improve upon the hint.

stanza.line: SOUL of the world, refulgent SUN,
Oh take not from my ravi∫ht fight
Tho∫e golden beams of living light,
Nor, ere thy daily cour∫e be run,
Precipitate the Night.
Lo, where the ruffian clouds ari∫e,
U∫urp the abdicated ∫kies,
And ∫eize the ætherial throne;
Sullen-∫ad the ∫cene appears,
Huge HELVELLYN ∫treams with tears,
Hark, 'tis giant SKIDDAW's groan!
I hear terrific LAWDOOR roar;
The Sabbath of thy reign is o'er,
The anarchy's begun;
Father of light, return; break forth, refulgent Sun!
What if the rebel bla∫t ∫hall rend
∫hese nodding horrors from the mountain's brow --
Hither thy glad deliverance fend,
Ah ∫ave the votari∫t and accept the vow!
And, ∫ay, thro' thy diurnal round,
Where, great Spectator, ha∫t thou found
Such ∫olemn ∫oul-inviting ∫hades,
Gho∫tly dells, religious glades?
Where Penitence may plant its meek abode,
And hermit Meditation meet its God.
Now by the margin of yond gla∫∫y deep
My pen∫ive vigils let me keep;
There, by force of Runic ∫pells,
Shake the grot where Nature dwells;
And in the witching hour of night,
Whil∫t thy pale filter lends her ∫hadowy light,
Summon the naked wood-nymphs to my ∫ight.
Trembling now with giddy tread,
Pre∫s the Mo∫s on GOWDAR's head;
But lo, where ∫its the bird of Jove,
Couch'd in his airy far above;
Oh, lend thine eye, thy pinion lend,
Higher, yet higher let me ∫till a∫cend:
'Tis done; my forehead ∫mites the ∫kies,
To the la∫t ∫ummit of the cliff I ri∫e;
I touch the ∫acred ground,
Where ∫tep of man was never found;
I ∫ee Nature's rude domain around.
Peace to thy empire, queen of calm de∫ires,
Health crown thy hills and plenty robe thy vales;
May thy groves wave untoucht by wa∫tful fires,
Nor commerce croud thy lakes with ∫ordid ∫ails!
Pre∫s not ∫o fa∫t upon my aking ∫ight
Gigantic ∫hapes, nor rear you heads ∫o high,
As if ye meant to war again∫t the ∫ky,
Sons of old Chaos and primæval Night.
Such were the heights en∫hrined BRUNO trod,
When on the cliff he hung his tow'ring cell,
Among∫t the clouds a∫pired to dwell,
And half a∫cended to his God.
The prim canal, the level green,
The clo∫e-clipt hedge that bounds the flouri∫ht ∫cene,
What rapture can ∫uch forms impart
With all the ∫pruce impertinence of art?
Yet pageant ∫treams, that roll in ∫tate
By the vain windows of the great,
Re∫t on your muddy ooze and ∫ee
Old maje∫tic DERWENT force
His independent cour∫e,
And learn of him and nature to be free,
And you, triumphal arches, ∫hrink,
Ye temples, tremble, and ye columns, ∫ink!
One nod from WALLAH's craggy brow
Shall cru∫h the Dome
Of ∫acerdotal Rome,
And lay her glittering gilded trophies low.
Now downward as I bend my eye,
What is thsat atom I e∫py,
That ∫peck in Nature's plan?
Great Heaven! is that a Man?
And hath that little wretch its cares,
Its freaks, its follies, and its airs;
And do I hear that in∫ect ∫ay,
"My lakes, my mountains, my domain?"
O weak, contemptible and vain!
The tenant of a day.
Say to old SKIDDAW, "Change thy place,"
Heave HELVELLYN from his ba∫e,
Or bid impetuous DERWENT ∫tand
At the proud waving of a ma∫ter's hand.
Now with ∫ilent ∫tep and flow
De∫cend, but fir∫t forbear to blow,
Ye felon winds, let di∫cord cea∫e,
And Nature ∫eal an element of peace:
Hu∫h, not a whi∫per here,
Beware, for Echo on the watch
Sits with erect and li∫tening ear
The ∫ecrets of the ∫cene to catch,
Then ∫welling, as ∫he rolls around,
The hoar∫e reverberated ∫ound,
With loud repeated ∫hocks
She beats the loo∫e impending rocks,
Tears down the fragment big with death,
And hurls it thund'ring on the wretch beneath.
Not ∫o the Naid, ∫he defies
The faithle∫s Echo, and with yelling cries
Howls on the ∫ummit of rude LAWDOOR's brow;
Then with a de∫perate leap
Springs from the rocky ∫teep,
And runs enamour'd to the lake below.
So the Cambrian min∫trel ∫tood
Bending o'er old CONWAY's flood,
White as foam his ∫ilver beard,
And loud and ∫hrill his voice was heard;
All the while down SNOWDON's ∫ide,
Winding ∫low in dread array,
He ∫aw the victor king pur∫ue his way;
Then fearle∫s ru∫h'd into the foaming tide,
Curs'd him by all his idol gods and died.

note.i: This alludes to the great waterfall of Lawdoor.

stanza.line: Ah! where is he that ∫wept the ∫ounding lyre,
And while he touch'd the ma∫ter ∫tring,
Bad Ruin ∫eize the ruthle∫s King
With all a prophet's fire?
Mourn him, ye naids, and ye wood-nymphs mourn,
But chiefly ye, who rule o'er KESWICK's vale,
Your vi∫itor bewail,
And pluck fre∫h laurels for his hallow'd urn;
He ∫aw your ∫cenes in harmony divine,
On him indulgent ∫uns could ∫hine,
Me turbid ∫kies and threat'ning clouds await,
Emblems, alas! of my ignoble fate.
But ∫ee the embattled vapours break,
Di∫per∫e and fly,
Po∫ting like couriers down the ∫ky;
The grey rock glitters in the gla∫∫y lake;
And now the mountain tops are ∫een
Frowning amid∫t the blue ∫erene;
The variegated groves appear,
Deckt in the colours of the waining year;
And, as new beauties they unfold,
Dip their ∫kirts in beaming gold.
Thee, ∫avage WYBORN, now I hail;
Delicious GRASMERES calm retreat,
And ∫tately WYNDERMERE I greet,
And KESWICK's ∫weet fanta∫tic vale:
But let her naids yield to thee,
And lowly bend the ∫ubject knee,
Imperial lake of Patrick's dale,
For neither Scoti∫h LOMOND's pride,
Nor ∫mooth KILLARNEY's ∫ilver tide,
Nor aught that learned POUSSIN drew,
Or da∫hing ROSA flung upon my view,
Shall ∫hake thy ∫overeign undi∫turbed right,
Great ∫cene of wonder and ∫ublime delight!

poem.note: This alludes to the Great Lake of Ul∫water, situated in Patterdale, i.e. Patrick's dale, a ∫cene of grandeur and ∫ublimity far ∫uperior in my opinion to the Lake of Ke∫wick.
poem.line: Hail to thy beams, O Sun! for this di∫play
What, glorious orb, can I repay?
Not MEMNON's co∫tly ∫hrine,
Not the white cour∫ers of imperial Rome
Nor the rich ∫moke of Per∫ia's hecatomb;
Such proud oblations are not mine;
Nor thou my ∫imple tribute ∫hall refu∫e,
The thanks of an unpro∫tituted mu∫e:
And may no length of ∫till returning day
Strike from thy forehead one refulgent ray;
But let each tuneful, each attendant ∫phere
To the late∫t time thy ∫tated labours chear,
And with new Pœns crown the fini∫ht year.

chap.title: ODE II to Dr Robert James.
chap.head: ODE II.
TO
Dr. ROBERT JAMES.

stanza.line: FRIEND of man's feeble race, victorious ∫age,
Great tamer of the fever's rage;
Thine, mighty Ma∫ter, is the art
To heal the father's bur∫ting heart;
'Tis thine Elijah-like to ∫ave
The widow's darling from the grave;
Thine in the very ga∫p of death
To re∫cue the convul∫ive breath,
And to a hu∫band's bo∫om give
Her, without whom I cea∫e to live.
Now from the chamber of the ∫ickly Ea∫t,
Scenting the bloody human fea∫t
Hither Death's haggard family repair,
Scattering contagion thro' the troubled air:
Where'er the dread forerunners come,
Prophetic of the ∫ick man's doom,
The raven and the ∫creetch-owl ∫ing
Their boding knell, and clap the carrion wing.
And ∫ee, fa∫t bound upon her ebon bier,
Frantic Fever in the rear:
Round her a vi∫ionary group
Phantoms, and dreams, and terrors troop:
Mark how ∫he rolls her ∫taring eyes;
Hark, hark, ∫he ∫creams, ∫he laughs, ∫he cries,
And now be ∫till -- ∫he faints, ∫he falls, ∫he dies!
Ah no; behold, ∫he starts again:
Cold, cold, thro' every ∫hivering vein
Runs the ∫lowly-creeping pain:
'Tis pa∫t tho∫e fiery ∫pots be∫peak
The glowing furnace in her cheek;
'Tis in her brain; it mounts, it burns,
She freezes and ∫he flames by turns.
Now on the very throne of life
Di∫traction reigns and mortal ∫trife,
The rebel arteries beat to arms,
And ∫hake her ∫oul with dire alarms;
Dread horrors ∫eize the toiling heart,
And circulate de∫pair thro' every part.
Daughter, hell-born of ∫in and death,
Pa∫s on and ∫top thy ∫tygian breath,
Deadlier than is the fatal bla∫t,
That ∫weeps Numidia's ∫ultry wa∫te:
And lo, where wrapt in clouds and fire,
Follows thy gaunt and gha∫tly fire:
On his pale ∫teed erect the monarch ∫tands,
His dirk and javelin glittering in his hands;
This from a di∫tance deals the ignoble blow,
And di∫patches the re∫i∫ting foe;
Whil∫t all beneath him, as he flies,
Dire are the to∫∫ings, deep the cries,
The land∫cape darkens, and the ∫ea∫on dies.
Oh thou, to whom ∫uch healing power is giv'n,
The delegate, as we believe, of heaven;
Here take thy interpo∫ing ∫tand;
Here wave thy medicated wand;
Or leave a charm to guard my door,
'Till the con∫uming plague be o'er.
-- But hark! what groan is this I hear?
Sad tidings for a father's ear;
See, where all pale my lov'd ELIZA ∫tands,
Cla∫pt in mute angui∫h her ∫ubmitted hands,
Angui∫h too genuine to ∫eek
Acquaintance with the blabbing cheek;
In her ∫oft eye one ray of hope appears,
A Chri∫tian's hope tempering a mother's fears:
The∫e downward on her dying Son are bent,
This upward with her pray'rs to Heav'n's high throne is ∫ent.
And now with calm deliberate tread
I reach the fever-tainted bed;
Ah, luckle∫s innocent, is that the hue,
Which Nature's ro∫eat pencil drew?
Ah, chang'd alas, is that the face,
Where beam'd of late ∫uch youthful grace?
Accur∫ed fever, why annoy
My gentle unoffending Boy?
Rather why did∫t thou not arre∫t
The full-gorg'd glutton at his fea∫t?
Or in a drunken revel ∫mite
The lewd profaner of the night?
No, the∫e ∫hall live, and Nature's toils
Repair what foul intemperance ∫poils,
And health and hope ∫hall deign to dwell
With harden'd convicts in their cell;
While ∫leep, which from his guiltle∫s pillow flies,
Shall clo∫e (O ∫trange to tell!) the game∫ters haggard eyes.
Is there no drug to cool that burning brea∫t;
No chance for one ∫hort moment's re∫t?
Is there no hope? -- 'Tis pa∫t -- I ∫ee
Art can no more: the re∫t is left for me.
Come then, this wonder-working charm receive;
The la∫t command thy father hath to give:
The dying youth all o'er convuls'd they rai∫e,
He to the la∫t the well-known voice obeys;
The mother aids the draught, and, as ∫he aids it, prays.
Soft awhile! let all be ∫till,
And wait high Heav'n's di∫po∫ing will.
Now in each other's eyes we ∫tare
With looks, that a∫k if Hope be there:
Mean while the magic drug, at ∫trife
With the dete∫ted foe of life,
Runs to the heart, mounts to the brain,
And vi∫its each corrupted vein;
Where'er it comes bids tumult cea∫e,
And hail the me∫∫enger of peace.
Now, lengthening on the li∫t'ning ear,
The ∫oft ∫ub∫iding ∫igh we hear;
His breath, a wint'ry ∫torm before,
That loudly la∫h'd the ∫ounding ∫hore,
Now ∫inks into a ∫ummer breeze,
That gently lifts the ∫welling ∫eas;
O'er his parch'd ∫kin a healthful dew appears,
The ∫tern di∫temper ∫heds repentant tears;
He ∫miles, he turns, he ∫leeps -- Oh joy! -- Begone, my fears!
Ha∫te then, my Mu∫e, tear down the oaken bough,
To crown the great Phy∫ician's brow;
See that the my∫tic branch is broke
From ∫age Apollo's delphic oak;
Then, dripping from Ca∫talia's ∫pring,
Hither the civic garland bring;
And as your tuneful fingers tye
The votive chaplet, rai∫e on high
Your founding notes; provoke again
A louder yet, and yet louder ∫train;
Then to the temple of immortal Fame,
And on the brighte∫t tablet ∫tamp his living name.

chap.head: FINIS
